remixed_from.author: Lies
remixed_from.title: Flex Box Snap Fit - A wooden box with a living hinge

title: Flex Box Snap Fit - A wooden box with a living hinge

description.text: Wooden jewelry box with living hinge and elastic strap

• Cut box from 3mm plywood so that hinge slits are parallel to the grain of the wood.
  • If desired, loosen the hinge by firmly (but carefully) pulling the lid section away from the bottom of the box -- stretching the wood between the hinge slits.
  • Sand away unwanted laser burn marks
  • To remove burnt wood smell, make a paste from white vinegar and baking soda and apply liberally, allowing it to absorb the odor for at least 5 minutes before rinsing off.
  • Allow box to fully dry before applying finish, if desired. I applied three coats of Howard brand "Butcher Block Conditioner", a food grade mineral oil, beeswax and carnauba wax mix. This protects the box, further helps cover any remaining burnt wood odor and gives it a nice finish (it brings out the wood grain a little more, although had a little too much of a green hue for my liking.) I would recommend staying away from a polyurethane finish because it will prevent the hinge from bending properly.
  • Attach an elastic band through holes to hold the lid shut when closed. I tied the elastic to small black buttons, but if the holes had been sufficiently small, I could have just tied a knot to hold it in place. You may want to modify the laser cutting template to match the size of elastic band you have.
  • If desired, glue a soft fabric (like velvet or felt) to the bottom of the inside of the box.

remixed_from.author: jamesarm97
remixed_from.title: Z Axis Anti wobble for Prusa I3

title: Anti-Wobble Anti-Backlash Auto Bed Probe for Prusa i3 (Cheapest)

description.text:
Update1 4/4/2016 :
-Using two endstops connected in series at either sides of the x axis will improve the leveling repeatability. Just flip the part and print for the X-idler side.
-Changing the probe grid points to 2 (4 points placed at the most rigid areas on the bed which are usually above the linear bearings will make z offset measurement more consistent.

This part is the cheapest and most effective improvement implemented on my homemade Prusa i3 . I designed this thing in the need for Auto Bed Probing, by remixing the design done by jamesarm97 -Thanks to him- and adding a holder for the micro switch from an old computer mouse.
Surprisingly, The print quality and machine reliability improved significantly in the following ways:
1.ANTI_WOBBLE : Better layer alignment by eliminating the tension between X - Z axes and preventing the bent Z screws making X axis wobble.
2.ANTI_BACKLASH : Basically preventing backlash by using two nuts and a spring separating them.
3.AUTO_BED_PROBE :Compensating for unlevel build platform by Auto Bed Probing and setting Z offset matrix which leads to perfect first layer adhesion and perfect finish on faces printed directly on glass (PLA).
4.Replacing the unfriendly Z end stop which required constant adjustment.

Changes in Configuration.h in Marlin Based Machines :

1- Inverting your Z min end-stop setting.
Normally, Z end-stop is closed when Z axis homes, We want it to be open when Z axiz homes.
const bool Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false;
2-Activating auto bed leveling by delete "//"

define ENABLE_AUTO_BED_LEVELING

3-Update these setting for the probing grid

define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 50

define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 150

define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 150

define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 50

3-Set the number of grid points per dimension. I wouldn't see a reason to go above 3 (=9 probing points on the bed)

define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_GRID_POINTS 2

4-Set the probe offsets :
These are the offsets to the probe relative to the extruder tip (Hotend - Probe)
As we directly use the hot end nozzle to probe bed , offset of X and Y will be zero. Setting the Z offset needs trail and error, set to zero in the first upload and re-set it by using a sheet of paper as the gauge and reading this value on LCD as the hot end touches the sheet.My measurements leaded to 1 mm offset which would be different depending on the build platform rigidity.

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

Start G-code for the slicing Software :
M104 S
G28 X Y
G1 X100 Y100
G28 Z
G29
G1 Z0
M109 S

description.text:
I looked for a filament splicer â€œthingiâ€ without finding much. So I knocked this one up. Surprisingly - it seems to work!
Itâ€™s based on having a hot tongue to lick the filament ends and butt them up while they are hot and sweaty. The re-shaping of the filament takes place by being forced through a PTFE tube while itâ€™s still malleable â€“ basically at the same time as the buttering up takes place.
The first splicing set-up made a very good bond but left a flange.  The next version seems to have moulded the flange back into the desired 3mm circular profile.

A carousel of sample shapes with different horizontal gaps to evaluate optimal distances for support material design.
This gauge was inspired by the designs "Sealed Ball Bearing" and "Fully assembled 3D printable wrench" by Thigiverse member barspin, where the necessary support structures where created in the CAD software with a certain gap of air.
With this gauge one can easily test the different adherence between the support surfaces and the 3D model ranging from 0.05 mm to 0.5 mm in steps of a twentieth of a millimetre.
Since 3D print tolerances can vary according to variations in 3D print settings and filament diameter, this gauge can be used to evaluate the best support gap before 3D modelling the structures in CAD.
Barspins original things can be found as follows:
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:143494
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:139268
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/barspin/designs/
    • By Creative Tools

  • Home - Things - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Youtube - Instructables - Instagram - Flickr - Vimeo - LinkedIn

• Download the complete carousel STL file or just a file for a specific gap value that you wish to evaluate.
  • 3D print it with your preferred settings
  • After 3D print, pry open the top part of the object and evaluate the necessary force and eventual damage to the surface
    Expect to find the following issues for this test:
  • Most gaps will adhere completely
  • Most gaps will generate bad lower surfaces
  • Some gaps will generate good support
  • No gaps will release with no effort. Some prying, bending and breaking will be necessary to separate the surfaces.
  • Some whitening of break surfaces can be expected. Use the flame of a lighter or torch swiftly to turn the plastic back into it's original colour.

description.text:
With my Ozito Rotary tool (like Dremel) I was supplied with a Flexi attachment, table clamp and a rod used to suspend the tool when used with the Flexi attachment. Even with this it was difficult to be precise when sanding small parts. So I designed and printed this Sanding table so I could fix the Flexi attachment to the table and make the job of sanding much easier.

The Sanding table is designed in 2 parts for easy assembly and also for easy printing.
There is only one area that needs support in the bbSandingTable2/3. The clamp can be printed without support. Once printed assemble the Clamp and Table 2 or 3 as needed and glue them in place with superglue.

bbSandingTable2 - Comes with a hole and plastic rivet/rod for fixing after assembly. bbSandingTable3 comes with a hole thru which you can fix a screw after assembly for added support. The clamp already has a nut to receive this screw. I have found that there is no need for this so use only if needed.

Once stuck, the complete unit just slides into the slots in the clamp and is then tightened to the table. The Flexi attachment is then inserted and tightened in place with a small screw/nut as shown.

Refer to the images for assembly.

If you have one of these clamps then this THINGI is designed specifically to fit it.

title: APEX Solstice Boxmod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This 'box mod' was originally made as a joke, people took it seriously so here it is:

Features an ergonomic grip, holes everywhere but still looks cool, handy dandy pre-drilled holes for screwing things down, has a flat bottom so it actually stands, battery tray slot so it doesn't slide everywhere, per-drilled magnet holes made to fit perfectly, belt loop clip stupid easy to install, more holes for battery venting, a wire cover that actually looks mildly OK, plus accompanying wire cover stilts so you don't have to glue everything in, or glue it all because who cares, ALL the shoddy soldering and wire work will be covered!!

*510 hole fits most 22mm fat daddy 510's

*Button hole fits 16mm sized buttons.

*Battery tray slot fits most dual 18650 battery trays, if however you find yours to be to tall the shorty battery tray in my other designs works perfect.

*Installation of the belt-clip attachment as well as wire cover requires easily found #4 Wood Screws.

*The magnets are from www.fatdaddysvapes.com - Zinc plated 3mmX3mm case magnets in N35 grade so it does not get pulled off paired with 6mmX2mm N48's. Or hell just google those magnet sizes, probably much cheaper elsewhere.

*This project was designed to save time and plastic but keep its structural integrity, hence the holes everywhere. They also serve as a nice surface for gripping!

*The various lids are just cosmetic, the idea was to have a walking billboard for a mod that screams different.

Things needed to put this together complete checklist:
3 - #4 Wood Screws for the wire cover & belt clip
4 - 3mmX3mm magnets for the case
4 - 6mmX2mm magnets for the battery cover
1 - 510 Connection
1 - 16mm Button
For the electronics:
1 - Reel of 14ga-18ga insulated copper Wire
1 - Mosfet IRLB3034
1 - 100kohm+ Resistor for Mosfet
1 - Dual Battery Tray
1 - Soldering Iron
1 - Reel of Solder
1 - Container of Rosin Solder Flux
Optional:
1 - Voltage Meter
1 - Print Voltage Reader Cover in my designs if using Wire Cover 3
1 - LED Light
1 - Resistors for LED

Disclaimer: Do NOT attempt to build this if you are unfamiliar on how to build a box mod or haven't done DIY kits yourself before successfully. I am not responsible for any damages that may occur as this is just a chunk of plastic that looks pretty (kinda).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

25

Notes:

Everything available was made to print with little to no problems on the settings above, you can 100% infill if you'd like however the strength of this mod at 25% is quite extraordinary and it would also take much longer so the point is mute but up to you. GL!!!

author: Neira

description.text:
I originally made this as a swag bag tchotchke for my 11-year-old son's birthday party. It is designed so that the kids could build it themselves and get an introduction to soldering and acquainted with micro-controllers, programming and making stuff. My only two design parameters is that it had to be easy and relatively cheap - it had to be under/around €10 and came in at €9.81 including the PLA for the case and 4 batteries.

I decided on the nano and the max7219 because I've used them both before and I knew there were libraries for them that were easy to use and I could get both for under €3 each, leaving around €4 for the rest of the parts.

Code revisions this can be found at https://github.com/leidentech/boloblinky

The program has different functions, which are incremented or decremented by long pressing the left or right button:

  • 6-side die - hit either button to roll the die

  • magic 8-ball type random advice giver - either button to get feedback

  • image editor - hit the left button to go through the matrix pixel by pixel and the right button to turn it on or off. When finished, long press either button to display the image

  • race game - hit left or right to navigate through the random road.

  • eyeball - animated eye that blinks and does crazy spins

  • timer - counts down a minute lighting up a pixel per second

The race game is something similar to one of the first programs I ever wrote on the Sinclair ZX81 a long time ago and reminiscent of the Mattel Electronics games I played in the '70s. I had ideas of other games but since there are only two buttons the possibilities are limited.

Build

OpenSCAD and STL files for this device can be found in the case directory. There is also an alternate design with the micro switches inside the case. My son preferred the switches on the outside.

Battery case:

place battery ends in the case so that the spring is at the end nearest the square plug bracket at the end where the switch is. Wire the nearest spring end underneath the bracket to the middle pin of the slide switch. Wire the nearest pin of the slide switch to the (-) end of the two pin plug passing the wire underneath and through the bracket.

Wire the farthest flat end on the same side with a red wire to (+) side of the two pin plug passing the wire underneath and through the bracket.

Switches and Nano wiring

Attach two wires with female plugs to the GND/VIN on the Nano next to the RST pin.

Wire the two pins nearest the bottom wall on the switches together and the two upper pins from the switches together, wire the middle pin on the switch nearest the Nano to D2 and the middle pin of the other switch to D3. Wire the remaining pin on the switch nearest the Nano to GND next to D2 on the Nano. Wire the remaining pin on the far switch with a female plug to go into the GND of the max7219.

Wire (with female plugs) the Nano's D10 to go to DIN on the max7219, The D11 to go to the CS pin on the max7219 and D13 to the CLK pin on the max7219. Wire the 5V pin on the Nano to the 5V on the max7219.

This wiring corresponds to the Nano code and the libraries used.

Plug all the wires into the max7219 correctly and place that in the opening flush with the face of the top. Bend the pins as necessary to make the fit tight. Slide the Nano into the slot so that the usb port is sticking out of the provided hole.

description.text:
This is based on Puzzle generator. It places a multiplication table on a puzzle. The piece's height, as the number shown, is in millimeter.

Parameters:

  • piece_side_length
  • same_side
  • n
  • spacing

Basically, the n parameter may be any positive value, but I restrict it from 1 to 9 in the Customizer because I don't want the number too small. The number size is piece_side_length / 3 is the .scad file.

If you want to generate a multiplication puzzle with a n bigger than 9. Download the .scad file and modify the size parameter of the text in the puzzle_piece_with_text module.

Find all my puzzles in puzzles collection.

title: Owl Facing Left - Negative Mold for Low Melt Metal in ABS Casting

description.text:
This is a basic mold for casting the Owl Statue Facing Left in low melting point
metals like Rose's Metal (208F), Field's Metal (144F), etc. Make sure to use
an alloy that won't exceed ABS tolerances. I recommend high quality "natural"
ABS with no dyes/colorants. You can soak off the ABS using hardware store
grade Acetone. Give the metal plenty of time to cool as it can take hours to
reach room temperature.

I recommend printing the mold with ~6 perimeters, 30% infill and print slowly
with no cooling fan for best interlayer bonding to minimize cracking as much
as possible. My first attempt, a 4 perimeter mold with 20% infill resulted in
molten metal leaking into the interior infill space. Most of the 5 perimeter
30% infill molds for this and other models I've made have gone well,
so 6 should be about perfect.

Have fun and keep it safe and sane. Hot metal can cause severe burns
VERY quickly and solvents are flammable and potentially poisonous
and need to be handled appropriately. Do your homework first.

comments.text: They were printed at about 87.5mm tall, which is about 60% size I believe.

comments.text: I love both of them!   How tall are they??
comments.author: cushwa

comments.text: I'll post some pictures, but be warned that this comes from what I consider a failed 1st attempt at casting. The mold I printed had a significant crack that the metal flowed out of and into the interior infill area and even out the outer wall of the mold a bit. Had to remove a whole bunch of bars of metal that had caged the actual model inside and the model has some prying marks as a result. The lower half of the model didn't turn out well either, due to having to recirculate partially cooled metal back into the mold to make up for the metal that leaked out. I am going to recast with a newly printed mold. More interested in seeing how that one turns out. I managed to make a second mold with 6 perimeters, slower print speed and ~30% infill percent that has basically zero cracks.

title: Ecstasy by Eric Gill - Mold for Low Melt Metal in ABS Casting

description.text:
This is a basic mold for casting Eric Gill's statue Ecstasy
in low melting point metals like Rose's Metal (208F), Field's Metal (144F), etc.
Make sure to use a metal that won't exceed ABS tolerances. I recommend
high quality natural ABS with no dyes/colorants. You can soak off the ABS
using hardware store grade Acetone. Give the metal plenty of time to cool
as it can take hours to reach room temperature.

I recommend printing the mold with lots of perimeters, 30% infill and print slowly
with no cooling fan for best interlayer bonding to minimize cracking as much as
possible. You may wish to try printing this vertically for best preservation of details.
If so, make sure you know how to get good bridging results out of your printer.
May wish to print vertically and upside down so that any poor bridging is hidden
in the base of the statue.

Have fun and keep it safe and sane. Hot metal can cause severe burns VERY
quickly and solvents are flammable and potentially poisonous and need to be
handled appropriately. Do your homework first.

UPDATE (3/29/2016) - Printing this mold vertically, with the heads closest
to the build plate, does work and looks like it produces a more detailed mold.
This can be done without support, but you will either want to manually
administer the print when it gets near the top or alter the G code to alter your speed,
temperature and even fan settings to get it to bridge the top in this orientation.
Print the rest slow, hot and without fan and then alter the settings to get the
bridge established and then back it off once you have a layer to build upon.
My bridge was quite messy (required some cleanup afterwards with xacto) and
spanning that initial 5 cm gap would have been impossible had I not altered the settings.

title: Foldable 5V solar panel to power or recharge  portable devices

description.text: This is a foldable multi-page solar panel based on inexpensive 100mmx69mm epoxy covered solar panels which can be bought on eBay for less than $3 a piece. One of these panels delivers 5.5V @ 150mA under optimal conditions (full sunshine at noon). So combining 5 of them in parallel, will result in a power source that easily delivers 500mA over most sunshine hours during the entire day. That power can be used directly via an USB cable to drive or charge any of your USB powered mobile devices or alternatively to "collect" the sun's energy in a Li-Ion USB power pack used from which you can charge your mobile devices later on. The challenge in this project was to combine several such solar panels in a foldable compact stack, so that I can take it along easily on all my trips. The STL files provided here are for a pack of 5 panels, but the SCAD file is parametrized to allow for any (reasonable!) number of panels in the pack. Also, it is of course possible to use solar panels with a different voltage and/or wire them differently in order to get a foldable solar panel for other purposes. _Update 2014-11-08: I just uploaded a new version of this foldable solar panel which uses larger 150x130mm solar cells that deliver 500mA at 5V each.__

The solar panels are mounted by sliding them under the two triangular corner that are included in the frame structure. Then the panels are fixated with 2 of the separately printed triangles, which are glued to the other 2 corners of the inner frame (I just "glue" them using acetone on my ABS prints). This is illustrated in the last photo.
Two adjacent printed frames are attached via two M3x10 screws that serve as axes of the hinges.
The panels are wired by connecting the plus poles of all pages together and then to pin 1 of the USB socket. Then all the minus poles are tied together and are connected to pin 4 of the USB socket. There are holes on each side of the frame through which wires are led through. When soldering the wires, make sure to leave enough (but not too much!) spare wire between the pages to allow proper folding.
The USB type a socket is soldered on a little piece of prototyping PCB (18x24mm) and slit into the USB socket box on the last (outermost) panel.

comments.author: Hedtrip

comments.text:
I don't want to put links to eBay or AliExpress here, as these links will usually only last for a few weeks. I suggest you search for something like "solar panel 5V 69mm" and see what is currently available and at what price. It might be that you don't find 100mm x 69mm panels, but
99mm x 69mm or 110mm x 69mm. In any case, it is very easy to adapt the SCAD source to the exact dimension of the panel, simply modify the parameters "Width" and "Length" according to size of your panels and regenerate the STL files.

title: Cylinder Cardboard Lamp (17 inch)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A lamp shade made out of laser cut cardboard.

Description of files:
23 arcs - This file contains 23 arcs whose inner and outer edges each have a different radius. As such, they can't be laid out very efficiently, so the laser will take about twice as long to cut these, but they are a little more visually appealing. I'll be using these to form the bottom two layers since that is the only layer where the cardboard thickness is visible. 30 nested arcs: This file uses a 17" diameter circle for the outer arc, and the same for the inner, so it doesn't have uniform thickness, but allows the arcs to be laid out very efficiently for the laser to cut. Since the outside edge of one arc is the inside edge of the next, the laser does almost half the cutting. fixture: The fixture layer is designed to have the same 17" diameter outside circle, but has connections leading to a smaller circle designed to fit an Ikea Hemma light fixture which can be had for $3.99 (http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/10175810/)

  • Cut the cardboard: ensure that corrugation of cardboard is aligned such that light can flow through the corrugation perpendicular to the long side.

  • Assemble rings: five arcs make up each layer of this lamp. I found it easiest to form the first two layers simultaneously: Set two adjacent strips on the lame layer next to each-other and glue a third strip on top of them so that it is covering up the inside half of each of the two strips on the base layer. Continue going around the circle in this fashion.

  • Stack as many layers as you want for the desired height, which will also depend on the thickness of cardboard used.

author: Moffa

description.text:
I will update this with more detail shortly but for now a full bill of materials and a build guide can be found on my blog at http://andrewtaylor.net.au/2016/03/26/215-hopper-build/

Update 1:
It has been brought to my attention that the original brd file that I upload had a fault on the vbat connector. The ground trace from said connector did not reach the main ground plane. Now uploaded is revision 2 of the board with this problem corrected.
My apologies to anyone who has already made the board. You will still be able to fly with it but you will need to forgo the connector for vbat and connect wires directly to the same pads as the battery leads (mind the polarity), or leave them off all together (mind you don't over discharge your batteries). I have ordered a new batch myself so if anyone has already made boards and would like a corrected replacement get in touch.

Instagram : 3dprintingtips

Specifications

  • Ø15 x 24cm print volume
  • Precision from 250 to 80 microns
  • Slicer : Cura
  • Heated bed & screen controller included

Bill of Materials

Mechanical parts :

  • 6x stainless steel smooth rod 500mm (Ø 8mm)
  • 9x stainless steel smooth rod 180mm (Ø 8mm)
  • 6x LM8UU bearings
  • 1x 500mm aluminium hollow rod (Ø 8mm)
  • 3x 20 tooth GT2 pulleys
  • 3x GT2 belt 1m
  • 4x 624ZZ bearings
  • 3x GT2 belt tensioner

Extrusion :

  • E3Dv6 hotend for 1.75mm filament
  • 2x 1/8" pneufit
  • 80cm PTFE tube (Ø 4mm)
  • 11mm extrusion wheel
  • 20mm spring

Heated bed (optional but recommanded) :

  • Thermoelectric heater (peltier effect) 40x40x4mm
  • Thermistor
  • 5mm cork sheet
  • Polyimide adhesive
  • Thermal pad

Electronics :

  • Arduino MEGA + RAMPS 1.4
  • 3x 30mm fan
  • 4x NEMA17
  • 4x stepper driver
  • ReprapDiscount Smart Controller
  • 12V 120W (or more) power supply
  • ON/OFF switch
  • 5.5/2.5 power plug
  • 3x endstops

Screws & Nuts :

  • 35x M3 16mm screw
  • 40x M3 "nylstop" nut
  • 40x M3 nut
  • 50x M3 10mm screw
  • 12x M3 10mm hex screw
  • 4x M4 25mm screw
  • 1x M4 10mm screw
  • 4x M3 30mm screw
  • M3 washers
  • M4 washers
  • 15x M2.5 20mm screw
  • 15x M2.5 nut

Printed parts :

  • 6x 150mm rod
  • 1x arduino support
  • 6x bed support part 1 & 2
  • 2x bottom frame
  • 1x bottom frame Z axis
  • 3x carriage
  • 1x e3d blocker
  • 1x e3d top
  • 3x foot
  • 1x extruder arm
  • 1x extruder body
  • 1x extruder support 1 & 2
  • 3x GT2 belt carriage
  • 1x hotend fans
  • 12x joint
  • 1x LCD front panel
  • 1x LCD front panel support
  • 4x LCD front rods support
  • 1x platform
  • 1x switch panel
  • 1x top frame
  • 1x top frame with spool holder
  • 1x top frame Z axis
  • 1x endstops tube fixing

Cutted parts :

  • 1x bed.dxf in 5mm thick aluminium

For any question or suggestion : contact[at]sculptr.fr
See it in action : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yEZaucU6Y_E
The future of the Sculptr project : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eGv1PW3HHeM

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 - 0.1mm

Infill:

20%

22 November 2016 : very big update on extruder, top frame, LCD front, carriage, platform, GT2 belt mount
26 October 2016 : extruder updated
18 September 2016 : fans support updated
6 September 2016 : bottom frame updated
26 August 2016 : important modification on the GT2 belt fixing
5 July 2016 : GT2 belt fixing updated
2 July 2016 : Cura configuration file added (SculptrDelta.ini)
27 June 2016 : new spring loaded extruder
24 June 2016 : extruder updated
19 June 2016 : new fixation of the endstops tube on the bottom frame
18 June 2016 : new top frame pieces
8 June 2016 : NEMA17 stepper motors easier to mount on the bottom frame pieces
24 May 2016 : extruder easier to print
19 May 2016 : corrected issue on the bottom frame
10 May 2016 : spool holder directly fixed on the top frame
9 May 2016 : stronger hotend fixation (hotend_fans.stl reuploaded, e3d_blocker.stl uploaded)
26 April 2016 : new pieces added + important changes on hotend_fans.stl
22 April 2016 : upload

Added 2016-05-13

//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
If you ask in comments or message me be patient as i started a new nightshift work that makes me pretty tired.
Only so you know.....

Update 2016-05-08 ( Nr 7 )

Uploaded repetier beta firmware to be used.

This works with there browser based easy to use configuration tool.

I use the same sockets to power the board to power the fan that cools the hotend so its fool proof to avoid clogged nozzles because you forget.

https://www.repetier.com/

Always be carfull when using beta firmware like this!!!!

Update 2016-04-17 ( Nr 6 )

Uploaded the last part so its now final and there will simply be upgrades and fine adjustements to parts now only.
the part is a z carriage extender and spacer.

Update 2016-04-16 ( Nr 5 )

Uploaded print cooler and my minimalistic addon to stiffen the z base a bit with longer threaded rods.

Update 2016-04-10 ( Nr 4 )

Uploaded new endstop holder designs.

Update 2016-04-07 ( Nr 3 )

Uploaded images so the ramps and lcd mount are more clear to put together.

Update 2016-03-28 ( Nr 2 )

Started uploading revision parts on things I have bin reported and requests.
The x carriage have bin changed so you now nead 47-50mm long m3 screws to attach the motor.
The original where done so you neaded to use a dremel to cut small bits of to fit the motor,it where done like that to make it easier to print.
Rev2 parts do not nead this anymore!!!

If you already printed the old x carriage and don't want to cut it so is there a motor spacer if you don't want to print the new one and waste plastic.

Also made a small revision on the Bowden mount as some builders thought they neaded to sand and grind to much to fit there Bowden.
I lowered the thicknes in this area with 0.25 mm so should work better.

Removed old x carriage as its obsolete and better with the new thicker one.
It do not impact the suggested print size on y as we now have 200mm long rod on y as default.
Keep suggestions coming but please post them here so its easier for me to track ;)

Temporary bom on the reprap wiki iam working on and not final.

It will be put here also when its more final and closer to be finished.

Its alive....
https://youtu.be/iiAD7D7nIw4

Bom will be added during a longer time :)

print_settings.Notes:: Print with an infill that gives sturdy bottom and walls. I used 35% with 22° rectangular infill and it came out great.

description.text:
Do you know those travel boxes for toothbrushes? Those that you put in your bag the day when you go on holiday, and once arrived take them out in a hundred pieces again? Or those that survive a journey but when trying to clean them break apart?

Well I wanted to have a toothbrush travel box that will survive both traveling and cleaning, so i designed a pretty sturdy one!
The walls are around 3mm thick, so it is not geared towards low material consumption.
It has small holes in the bottom part to let the toothbrush dry while inside, also keeps building up of toothpaste residue down.

Beware that the box is more then 20cm long, so if your print area is only 20cm you might have to print it diagonally.

Printer:

P3 Steel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Print with an infill that gives sturdy bottom and walls. I used 35% with 22° rectangular infill and it came out great.

author: Rolf62

print_settings.Notes:: My counter weight of flying extruder uses two pulleys.

description.text:
Parts:
Pully support x1 (printed part)
V groove wheel x1 (printed part)
623Z bearing x1 (OD 10mm, ID 3 mm)
M3x15 bolt x1
M3 nut x2
M3 washer x2

Assembly:

The inner diameter of V groove wheel is set 4.8 mm to press fit the bearing. I used press fit technique. To press fit the bearing into the wheel, heat up the bearing for three to four seconds using a portable gas torch or lighter. Then push the bearing into the hole, press it by C clamp or bench vise.

To use M3 set screw, change the diameter of bearing_623Z() to 5.0.
module bearing_623Z()
{
cylinder(r=4.8, h=4+2); // 4
}

Put two M3 washers in left and right side of the V groove bearing.
Fasten the V groove bearing on the support using M3x15 bolt and one M3 nut.
The V groove wheel should turn without rubbing the inner wall of the support.

Printer:

Bulbul Junior

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print the support and V groove wheel at the same time.

My counter weight of flying extruder uses two pulleys.

Pulley of the counter weight system

Previous pulley that uses 623Z bearing made the string digging into the gap between the bearing and support while in printing. So I went out to buy V groove bearings in local suppliers. I went home with great frustration. 'Why should I buy this kind of simple part from other country?'

I decided to build a V groove bearing and searched models on thingiverse, and found one but it was overly complicated. After studying the SCAD design, I borrowed core design, merging two identical cones at the center.

Press fitting 623Z bearing into the V groove wheel makes V groove bearing!

title: Rotatable Webcam Mount for a Computer Screen

description.text:
Webcam mount for a PC display. It slightly elevates a webcam, so that it doesn't cover any part of the screen.
The top part is rotatable, which enables adjustment of the camera angle.

Please note that the peg and the hole are designed with the same diameter, meaning that the assembly in the "raw" condition is not possible. Postprocess the peg with a sandpaper at the desired diameter that gives you a nice and tight contact between both parts.

description.text: This piece is for calibrating overhang and retraction settings on your 3D Printer. It has four overhangs (35, 45, 55, and 65 degrees) measured from the vertical with the numbers to be printed on top for reference. Each of the four overhangs is split apart far enough that it can be used to test the retraction settings of your printer. The ideal outcome is to not have any strings between the overhang towers and no droop under the overhangs.
We found our ideal settings to be 2.5mm of retraction at 40mm/s using Slic3r on Repetier Host. These settings are for the MakerGear M2.

This stand for a Galaxy S5 brings the sound from the rear speaker out to the front. The charging cable can be used while in the stand. This was designed to be printed on a 6" printer bed

EDIT:
3/31/2016:

  • Changed the size and height of the mounting posts to improve mounting and printing.
  • Added a groove in the side which allows access to the SD card at any time.

This is a part of my power-reducing project involving the M3D, a handy mount for placing the Raspberry Pi A+ on the M3D frame!

But why would someone want to do this?
Well, considering the print spooler program for the M3D is required to be running the entire time the M3D is printing, the computer must be constantly on.
For me, running a pretty heavy computer setup can run my electricity bill pretty high for a simple print.

Solution: use a Raspberry Pi as a print spooler instead!
Using Octoprint http://octoprint.org and
M3D's Linux compatibility freeware http://plugins.octoprint.org/plugins/m3dfio/
the M3D can be completely ran off of the Pi! Just send the files via Wifi and use the Pi to manipulate and print the object.

So far this design is only oriented for the A+ model. If I see that there are some people who are interested in this I will try to make orientation versions for the other models.
The screw holes are for 2mm thread screws, as this correlates to the Pi's mounting holes. If using a raft the holes may be a bit difficult to clean. Just take care!
The mounting design was based off of ilikesanta's "clamps" All I needed to do was to add the bracket for the Pi.

description.text:
Tired of having to get up to throw away all of those pesky pre-printing extrusions or wasted projects? Well here is a little design that can add a little waste bin to the M3D!

This adds a little convenience to your messed up prints (happens to all of us) and helps with keeping track of the wasted filament if you plan on having it re-spun to new filament spools. The design is a bit hefty but is small enough to be printed by the M3D.

My wife saw the new AxiDraw and wanted one.
http://shop.evilmadscientist.com/846
Unfortunately they will start shipping in June. So I had to do it myself during Easter holidays :-)

I am not yet done but progress is being made and as it seems to piece together nicely I think I can share it. AxiDraw is advertised as Open Source so I hope I am not stepping on anybodies toes here (if so let me know).

Please note that I have not yet mine up and running so I cannot make any claim about how well it works. We just saw the online video and were hooked.

My first mock-up is based on laser cut parts but my plan is to do a fully 3D printed version.

STEP source and STL files are provided. Please note some parts may need to be rotated to be printed without supports.
Or you can use the Onshape public document to do the same: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/236f46681d1cbe31f6d52db0/w/5948c0b4f86507971afed68c

And now it starts to move ... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_V3bHmOuxTI&feature=em-upload_owner with then new ends that hold the motors down instead of up.

And to draw: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xPq4ciNnNnw

Update

New and improved pen holder and pen carriage and belt tensioner.

I have added a taller part for those with 48mm tall stepper motors too.

Building details and links to code can be found here http://www.instructables.com/id/4xiDraw/

You can have a 3D view of the complete system here http://a360.co/1N6b6tD

Zerginator user has created a FreeCAD model assembly and is kindly sharing it too: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B0IYEtpw-9WNYWxpWlduVDdLMUk/view?usp=sharing

Bill of materials

2 nema 17 steppers ()
4 8mm smooth rods (two 400mm-long and two 320mm-long)
8 LM8UU
2 GT2 pulleys
10 F623ZZ bearings
1 micro servo SG90 (plus a 250mm cable extender)
1 Arduino UNO
1 CNCshield
2 Pololu stepsticks
1 GT2 belt ( 1.4 meters long )
2 M10 threaded rods (400mm-long each)
8 M10 nuts
8 30mm M3 screws with nuts
8 6mm M3 screws
4 16mm M3 screws with nuts
4 M3 washers
2 4mm OD, 100mm-long carbon fiber tubes
2 15mm M3 screws
1 12V 2A power supply
1 USB cable
1 felt tip pen (or many for more fun)
() Stepper motors should be 40mm or shorter, unless you chose the taller parts that I later created for some users willing to use 48mm tall steppers (like many use for 3D printers).

comments.text: An eventual shift on the pen location is usually due to missed steps. Reducing acceleration and max feed rates can help and so can raising motor's current. If repetitive you can see where the problem happens and try to avoid that pattern. Other than that, it may happen due to the open-loop nature of stepper motor control. You just one to operate it in a way that trouble does not strike you often.

comments.text: You need to power it in a way the Arduino gets power from the motors supply. Servo may need a bit more power than USB may deliver in some cases, so that might froze the Arduino (and so stop further communication). On the other hand, please be aware Arduino may have trouble with supply voltages over 12V. Power should be on before even connecting with UGCS.

comments.author: misan

comments.text: A power supply problem is what it looks like. I understand you have triple checked the servo connection and the power supply connection. As the servo apparently works ok with your test software my diagnose is still the same. You can check it without the CNCShield to remove components and see what happens. Arduino becoming unresponsive after first motion of servo indicates this motion causes some system problem. Why this does not happen with your test problem might well be explained if your test program does slow and smooth motion as ours is usually not the case. Fast motion requires more energy.
comments.author: funshanas

comments.text: Problem solved. Now is working fine. I'm using MI Inkscape extension with Inkscape 0.45 version. This extension does not work with newer versions of Inkscape.

I am having a few difficulties with the servo. I'm using grbl-servo, CNC Shield v3.0 and a Y-3009 servo von D11, +5V and GND from the shield. The shield is powered by a 12V source.
I can move the servo via M03 S... command, but most of the times only once and afterwards there is an connection error to the gcode sender. After reconnection it works again (once). The steppers are working fine.
I tried different servos, shields (even soldered my own shield), power sources and powering the arduino via USB and via V_in. I am pretty much out of ideas. Any suggestions?
comments.author: Freakazoid

comments.text: I am afraid the peak power the servo demands causes a transient that freezes the Arduino board. You may try a smaller servo or power the servo from another 5 - 6 volts supply and not from Arduino's 5V rail.
comments.author: Freakazoid

comments.text: That was the solution. I hooked up a 5V supply to the servo and now it works correctly. Thank you!

comments.text: The slot in the tensioner part is to hold a loop of the belt, teeth against teeth, with a toothpick or M3 screw at the end of the loop, that cannot go through the slot. Dust Collector Fitting to adapt from 4 inch PVC female fitting (90,Tee,etc) to a 2.5 inch vacuum hose. This fitting is a double male fitting meant to go from a PVC fitting to a hose fitting. The Fusion 360 source is located at http://a360.co/21LTTwf if you need to make changes. The cap to the 2.5" end can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1445427

description.text:
This project was motivated by my attempts to spray paint my 3D prints - essentially, it's an electronically controlled turn table which can be used for painting, possibly 3D scanning or just presenting other models.

The project was designed with openjscad and the customisation options can be found here:

http://www.geminidev.be/3d/openjscad/#examples/doodatable

The BOM for the project are:

  • 1 x roll of Painter's tape
  • 1 x Arduino or compatible device
  • 1 x 28BYJ-48 Stepper Motor 5V
  • 1 x ULN2003 Driver for the motor
  • 3 x 16mm Marbles or steel balls
  • 2 x Microswitches
  • 10 x Connecting wires (male/male)
  • 1 x 400 point Breadboard

Though I'm sure there are lots of alternatives to this if you don't mind hacking the Arduino code or doing some soldering.

I've provided some female/female connector parts for the motor - if you want to print these, my suggestion is to slice at 0.25mm layers and print slow.

The main models can be sliced at 0.3mm. There are two variants provided - the default one which has a radius of around 9cm and the small version which has a radius of 5cm.

Circuit and Arduino code can be found here:

https://123d.circuits.io/circuits/1836987-the-doodatable

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

As noted in the main comment, the optional motor connectors are best printed at 0.25mm and printed slow.

title: C-3PO Antenna
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A model of C3PO's head antenna, based on one that came with my head, and from pictures online. Useful as a replacement, or as a greeblie on your own costume. Modeled in 123D Design.

I have printed it both standing up and laying down, and both have their issues. When vertical, the print has a weak point along the main shaft, and it can snap pretty easily (as shown in the pictures). When laying down, the print might be a little rough on the bottom edge. I think with some tweaking of the print settings, this can be minimized. Overall, I prefer the laying down version, because the rough spot can be oriented against the rest of the head, and mostly hidden.

description.text:
My friend lost one of the clips that fits on the parcel shelf of his new Mitsubishi Colt car, so I thought I'd treat it as a learning project to draw the item in Cobalt (wonderful software BTW, well done Ashlar) and 3D print it - maybe someone else has lost one too :-)) It should save a pile of money if you have to purchase a completely new shelf.
Pic shows two mirrored clips with the original below.

Original printed in black 1.75 mm PLA at 180 degC - 0.1mm layers.
Had an issue with printing both at the same time, so have included the individual left and right mirrored items.

description.text:
This is my first upload to thingiverse.

I wanted to use my iPhone 4s with a Google Cardboard (actually it was the viewer from http://3d-vr-viewer.com/cardboard/ but it should be the same) but unfortunately the phone was too small to get attached accurately into the VR glasses. So I took the lenses out of the viewer and made my own design optimized for the iPhone 4s. I optimized the distance between the display and the lenses and placed them a bit narrower to each other to adapt to the small screen of the iPhone. It works much better than the original viewer. Because of the round shape it is also more comfortable to use.

Attached you will find the viewer profile as a QR code. Use this to set your viewer profile in your VR application.

The design consists of two parts that have to be bolted together with four M4 screws. I recommend using black filament to reduce reflections inside the viewer. You can use a belt of 20 mm width as headband.

Please let me know if you like this thing :)

description.text:
Something I really missed on this site and decided to make it myself: An actual dragon cup. The tail is the straw. It should be fully closed. I haven't printed it yet, but I will eventually. If you print it, please take a pic of it and upload it here so I can see how it worked out. If it isn't printable I'll edit it so that it IS printable. Anyway, have fun with your very own dragon cup, and drink from the blood of your slayed enemies while the dragon stares at your live ones.

Important note: it's now 6 bloody millimeters in size... Unless you have a VERY precise printer and like extremely small cups and tiny dragons, I suggest scaling it up a bit to your preference.

The license says: "NO SELL" but honestly, we can talk about it. Just message me and we'll see

description.text:
This is my concept of a Filament storage shelf.
I used 12 mm steel rods for the connection between the brackets, but you can also use wood or aluminium pipes. Maybe it will bend a bit in the middle in this case i also created an bracket to support the middle.

You shoud print this in ABS oder PETG. I didn´t tryed it in PLA

RepRap

Printer:

I3 Steel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

25-30 % (triangular or honeycomb)

Notes:

I printed it with a 0.4 nozzle with 4 perimeters for stability. Do not use less then 25% infill. You maybe need a brim.

I desiged the parts to fit well on a 20 x 20 cm Printbed.

The size of the holes is 12.2 mm diameter

you should need about 100 gramms each part.

I also added some simple screw coverplates :-)

Have fun with it and share your pictures with us!

comments.text: I keep about as much filament as you do on hand.  I keep them all in lidded, large plastic containers with all the silica gel packs I get with each one.  I have issues with from time to time when using filament rolls that have been around for a while.  It breaks.  Maybe, 12 inches or so away from the extruder it will break.  Do you experience this with older rolls?
comments.author: Galaktican

comments.text: Yeah i know this problem. I stored my rolls now for over 8 month similar like on this shelf with no realy problems. The only things that i take care of is: no direct sunlight, dry air and no dust. I once had problems with older filaments but i think much of it depends of the quality. I had noname, medium and premium ABS,PLA and PETG, all between 5-9 month old. the cheap one started to break easily but all other were still very good.

author: Pozitivka1

title: Bed Leveling M3 Nut Holder for Mix G1 Printer

description.text:
After printing multiple times I would see the quality of the prints go downhill. I soon realized that the bed was becoming more unlevel with every print. This was because the nuts were spinning themselves off as the printer vibrated while printing. This holder stops that by holding the nut in place and not letting it rotate.
This is also a time saver when it comes to fine tuning the levelness of your bed because you no longer have to use a pair of pliers to hold the nut while turning the screw. This part was designed in SolidWorks 2012 for the Mix G1 Printer M3 nut
http://www.mixshop.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=44_4&products_id=185

This part is optimized for low quality printers that have difficulty printing accurate small circles thus explaining why it is oriented sideways. Other positions and quantities are included in the downloads. Print part with your normal settings. Use a file to smooth the inner sides of the hexagon.
Do NOT make the hole big enough for the nut to fall through, only slightly smaller. Take a lighter and apply heat briefly to both sides of hexagon and quickly place the holder onto the nut.* The hexagon with be a tight and secure fit for the nut that won't let it fall out by accident. Install on printer by replacing the plain nuts. *Applying too much heat with lighter will cause warping. Heat only enough to get the nut to fit. It was less than a second per side for me.

Remix of 'H3R0M4T3's Safety Razor' ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:763815 )

remodeled handle with Geomagic freeform.

instructions by H3R0M4T3

BUY INSTRUCTIONS :
Buy at least one M4 bolt with a length of 16mm and two M4 nuts to fit on (in my case the material has been brass, but you can take any metal you want, except uranium.. that is bad stuff).

PRINT INSTRUCTIONS :
For printing the model, take a slow printing speed (32mm/sec) and give the model a density of at least 32% and a wall thickness of at least 0.8mm. Well that's what i would recommend, but i know, that you know your 3D-Printer a lot better than i do.

BUILD INSTRUCTIONS (reference to the pictures) :
Step 1 :
Insert the nut into the mount at the handle.
Step 2 :
Screw the bolt from the bottom of the handle through the nut on the top and give it a nice, but gentle last turn (PLA is durable, but not indestructible ;)
Step 3 :
Insert the second nut into the mount at the top-head-razor-blade-bracket
Step 4 :
Sandwich the head together (If this is the first bringing together of all parts, leave the head without the razor blade in order to prevent injuries)
Step 5 :
Screw the handle into the top nut of the head (needs some force, but not brute force)
Step 6 :
Turn the handle until the top thinner part can't be seen anymore. (This takes probably brute force)
Step 7 :
Take the cap and push over the razor head. The bolt will refuse to get pushed into the cap, but this is constructed in that way, to achieve a nice and snug fit of the cap. So take your time, push is a few times in and out , to make a nice slot for the bolt, IF IT IS STICKING OUT OF THE HEAD !

Congrats, you build your very own safety razor <3

"Step 8" :
If you insert the blade, try to push is to one long side of the head.
This will give you a more aggressive side (more blade is exposed) and a more gentle side (obvious, less blade is exposed).

This is a keychain that any guy would like. It is the perfect size for any set of keys. The keychain was designed in Illustrator and printed on a CNC Lazer Printer. You can personalize this keychain to add what you like and what to illustrate.

• Find a pictures from google images that you like, then copy and paste the image into a 4 inch. by 4 inch document in Illustrator.
  • Edit the image in Photoshop and in Illustrator to your liking
  • Draw one elispe shaped oval with the "elispe tool" or use any other shape tools to create the shape of the keychain
  • Make the shape a vector cut (change stroke to .001 size). Inside add a the same shape as a boarder if you want (stroke size to 1)
  • At one of the ends of the keychain add a circle for the key hole (highlight and make vector cut at .001).
  • To personalize the keychain add a name or initials to the bottom or side of the keychain.
  • Adjust overall size to desire of the size you want your keychain (highlight and click one of the arrows at the corner of the shape to adjust).
  • Now you are finished with your keychain!
    • Settings:
    Printed on CNC Lazer Printer
    Black Acrylic *Vector Cutting
    Speed: 12
    Power: 100
    Frequency: 5,000 *Raster Settings
    Speed: 50
    Power: 100

title: Fleks3d Clip for Makerbot 5th Gen Printbed

description.text:
Clips to hold Fleks3D plate and frame in place and to avoid warping.

To make the best out of a Makerbot 5th generation, i tuned it up with the Smartextruder+ as well as Fleks3D printbed ( i purchased the Replicated 2 5th Gen kit with 2 plates + frame from http://www.fleks3d.com/).

So when i printed a large flat objekt, even the thick Fleks3D warped up and my print failed with filament jams (... thats what every Makerbot 5th gen user is used to. it got better with SE+ but still not ideal).

2016-03-28: Added version v3 STL file. As mine got after a while a little looser I tightened them a little and slanted the uper claw of the clip to make sure that the pressure gets onthe fleks3d plate and not its frame.

So in order to avoid warping, I have created 4 clips that hold the Fleks3D frame as well as printplate in place.

Hope you find it useful.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20% diamond

Notes:

Printed on Fleks3D without rafts. 4 shells, 20% infill.

Notes: I needed to finetune the leveling by hand to get the print without rafts working.
i didnt use the glass disc that came with Fleks3D but instead simply used a sheet of paper to prevent the extruder touching the Fleks3D plate during auto-leveling process.

description.text:
This is a tube for carrying a spare 26650 battery. I needed something to carry an extra battery around for my vape, that would protect it and prevent it from accidentally coming into contact with something metal. The lid screws nicely onto the tube and provides a tight seal. The battery (at least for the purple Efest I have) fits like a glove, absolutely no rattling at all.

Printed with a Davinci Jr. with PLA.

Printer:

XYZPrinting Davinci Jr.

Notes:

Printed using a 10 mm brim. Without it the tube got knocked off of the bed, as it is very tall and narrow.

print_settings.Notes:: All parts are designed to not need any supports.

description.text:
This is a lightpainting tool created to use acrylic glas "blades".
I have created caps that can be used with regular flashlights already (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1316926) but when using a flashlight you are dependent on colored gels most of the time if you want color.
This tool is designed to use a common 1W RGB LED and a micro controller powered by a 9v battery. With this design you can use the full power of the RGB controller to create your images.
For example images please check out my other design for flashlights from the link above.

I haven't had the time yet to create a full assembly instruction, but i think it is pretty straight forward.
There top part holds the LED in place, it should be a tight fit for regular star pcb mounted LEDs. There is also a hole for a push button in this part.
The bottom part holds the controller and a power switch and the 9v battery.
You can see some photos of the assembly steps.
The switch in the bottom part is supposed to be between the controller and the battery and acts as a main power switch. The button in the top is supposed to be in the common line to the LED (+ in the one i used) and acts as a button to switch the light on/off independent of the controller. A small hole in the side is for the IR sensor of the controller. There are small holes in the inside of the part so you can use cable ties to fix the sensor in place.
Once the LED, controller, button, switch and battery clip are soldered together you can screw to top part to the bottom part. The threading has only a few windings so the cables from the electronics aren't stressed too much.

As mentioned earlier the top part uses the same design to put caps in like the design for flashlights. I included a cap for a 3mm acrylic glass sheet, if you need different thickness please use the ones from my other design.

I hope the design and assembly is easy understandable, if there are any questions please don't hesitate to ask ;)

Printer:

P3 Steel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

35%

Notes:

All parts are designed to not need any supports.

Used Electronics

3W RGB LED sometimes also be found as 1W since each color has 1W.

mini RGB LED controller make sure you get one with variable voltage, because in this tool a 9V batterie is used and there are some that only work at 12V

batterie clip to connect the 9V batterie

push button switch to toggle light without switching of the controller. This model has the advantage that it acts as a button and a switch, so you can switch on light only momentarily and also constant. I didn't find the model I used on international amazon, but the one in the link should be pretty close.

mini toggle switch acting as a power switch between battery and controller.

Depending on the LED you use you will need resistors to drop the voltage down for each color. Keep in mind that each color has 1W, so you will need resistors that have at least 1W rating. Also keep in mind that pretty often red has a lower forward voltage then the other two colors, so you want to put a smaller resistor on the red line to get the right color mixing. There are good online calculators out there you can use to calculate the correct resistors for the LED you use.
You will also need a couple of wires to solder it all together.
I love my cheap speakers (link) so I made a wall mount for them.

comments.text: That port is really important for the sound though! Putting the speakers up against a wall or putting things into the port will affect its performance - mainly bass.
comments.author: kanamin

comments.text: The port is not completely obstructed, and there is some room between the port and the wall. I did not notice any sound difference on their performance, but physically and acoustically your comment makes sense.

description.text:
This is a scan of a stone bust of a Buddha / Guanyin statue made in collaboration between myself and Alex Gao of Moment3D (https://www.3dhubs.com/talk/thread/moment-3d).

The scan was made with an Artec Eva. We missed some of the geometry on the top and undersides, but wanted to upload this anyways in case you want to use parts of the geometry for other purposes. Not guaranteed 3D printable as-is, check in your software/ slicer first.
